title: Sara Peters Grozelier
text:
Sara Peters Grozelier (1821–1907) was an American painter of <a href="portrait%20miniature">portrait miniature</a>s. Her name is sometimes given as Sarah.
Little is known of Grozelier's life and career. She was born in <a href="Andover%2C%20Massachusetts">Andover</a>, <a href="Massachusetts">Massachusetts</a>, the youngest of the twelve children of John and Elizabeth Davis Peters; her elder sister was the miniaturist <a href="Clarissa%20Peters%20Russell">Clarissa Peters Russell</a>, whose husband <a href="Moses%20B.%20Russell">Moses</a> was also a miniaturist. She graduated from Andover's Abbott Academy, where she learned painting and drawing, in 1836, and spent the next few years painting miniature portraits of prominent locals before moving to <a href="Boston">Boston</a> at the age of twenty-six. In 1855 she married the <a href="France">French</a>-born <a href="Leopold%20Grozelier">Leopold Grozelier</a>, a portraitist and lithographer. In that year she showed three miniatures at the <a href="Boston%20Athenaeum">Boston Athenaeum</a>. The following year she showed another, at the <a href="Brooklyn%20Art%20Association">Brooklyn Art Association</a>, under the sobriquet "Madam Grozelier". In 1866, after her husband's death, she was listed in the Boston directory; she was listed there again between 1877 and 1883. She also produced lithographs, and after her husband's death supported herself by painting over photographs in oil or pastel. At sixty-one she returned to <a href="North%20Andover%2C%20Massachusetts">North Andover</a>. The Grozeliers had no children.
Grozelier and her husband are buried at the <a href="Ridgewood%20Cemetery">Ridgewood Cemetery</a> in Andover. A portrait of two girls by her is in the collection of the <a href="Metropolitan%20Museum%20of%20Art">Metropolitan Museum of Art</a>; the date of the watercolor-on-ivory painting is unknown. A self-portrait, dated to between 1845 and 1855, is currently owned by the North Andover Historical Society.
